ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Guest lecture style classes are hard to generalize as a group. Guest's lectures were hit or miss. Jessica didn't do much instruction. But she does care a lot. The field trips were interesting. There need to be more project options. The class is definitely what you make of it.
This course is highly depepndent on the sustdents project and initiative. you make it what you want.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Very open ended. Not necessarily going to get a lot of feedback, but I bet if you ask for it, you would. I just never asked. I was only moderately invested in my project. But it was great to have a real work project.

Practical experience is invaluable to getting a good job, especially in the legal field. I was able to use my clinic experience to write a narrative letter for a subdivision approval application, which is an incredible thing to have on your resume if you want to work in land use law. Jessica was supportive and was a really fantastic teacher.
The field trips
I enjoyed the opportunity to engage with practitioners and experts in the field of land use law. Field trips were also very enjoyable.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Maybe creating more of a coherent narrative over the arch of the course. The guests seemed to talk about whatever...and it was hard to follow the thread throughout....

I feel like the class lectures were very disjointed. I understand that is the nature of capstone course that brings in different speakers every week but sometimes it was difficult to understand what was going on.
it seemed like there was a bit too much of a focus on revitalizing blighted cities in the northeast. Would have been nice to get a speaker or two from a different region and broader land use topics.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I really do like clinic courses that afford the opportunity to work with real world partners. Sometimes you get great partners, sometimes less than great. Ours was decent. No complaints! Definitely have good learning opportunities when you have clients.
This gave me great practical experience and a resume-builder for my land use legal career.

This class was very well integrated into my program and served as a good culmination of my experience and knowledge. I appreciated the chance to work independently but have a great resource in Jessica as I progressed on my project.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It's the easiest capstone. I had a very busy schedule. It was a requirement. I wanted a client based project.
To get more practical land use legal experience and learn Connecticut land use law.
To become more familiar with the land use planing process in practice. This class fulfilled this need/want.
I am required to take a capstone course and this course was the most appropriate for my interests.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I'm pretty satisfied with the course. I didn't have super high expectations, and it definitely met them.

Absolutely, I learned about CT land use law (it is somewhat different from NY where I've been doing research for the past 2 years) and got great experience working with a Pace Law alum in Greenwich, CT. My project is an excellent resume-builder and my supervisor is also helping me develop my legal connections in CT.
Yes
Yes, I felt I was able to take the things I've learned from previous classes and use them towards my project effectively while incorporating the new ideas presented by Jessica and the guest speakers.
Yes, the project was fun and interesting and opened some doors for me professionally.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: n/a
My team mate was a good friend of mine. And he is great. We worked really well together. This was definitely a highlight of the class!

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Have a developed project idea in mind.

It would be best if you had a good idea of the type of project you wanted to work on, and especially the ability to choose a partner and work on your own project. It can be as difficult or not as you make it. No exams..just a final project paper (and that kind of depends on your project)
You should absolutely take this course. Practical experience is invaluable to one's professional development.

It's a valuable experience if you're interested in pursuing an individual project in the are of Land Use and urban development. It's a course that gives you lots of flexibility and opportunities to engage with practitioners and create something useful.
